OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Changed needle to yellow butterfly needle and made top right inset smaller
Image REVISION: Added pressure cap and syringe to end of catheter; added a clear dressing over catheter site

In the inset, rotated the tubing and the butterfly 180 degrees so that they are both pointing down toward the middle of the body instead of over the shoulder; added the label “Inserting needle into Port-a-cath”, and removed the double-headed arrow from between the fingers

Moved the Port-a-cath inset to the left side of main figure; in main figure, shortened the catheter going from the port-a-cath so that it doesn't look like it's going to the heart; updated Blood drawn from Port-a-cath inset by showing the hands of a health professional inserting a needle into the port-a-cath and adding the part of the body where the port-a-cath sits; positioned tubing and blood draw so that it's over the right shoulder of patient

Changed the upper case C in the title to lower case (Port-a-cath); in the right bottom inset, changed the shading in the the area above the port-a-cath to white so it looks like there is a mound sticking up (from someone laying on their back), and changed shading in the area right around the port-a-cath and below it to look like tissue.
Turned the bottom inset box so that it is apparent that the patient would be lying down while blood is being drawn; Made the tube less full of blood

Removed the large inset showing the enlarged version of the port a cath; on the right side of the image, made two inset boxes, the top box showing the part of the body where the port a cath is inserted, but as a bump under the skin, and the bottom box showing the needle stuck into the port a cath, a tube connected to a syringe and a red-top tube to illustrate how blood is drawn through the port a cath.

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Port-a-cath (Port); drawing showing a port-a-cath under the skin in the right side of the chest. It is attached to a catheter that is threaded into a large vein above the right side of the heart called the superior vena cava. The left inset shows the port-a-cath under the skin. The right inset shows a needle being inserted into the port-a-cath and blood being drawn from the port-a-cath through a syringe attached to the needle.

Captions.MediaCaption: Port-a-cath (Port). A port-a-cath is a device that is usually placed under the skin in the right side of the chest. It is attached to a catheter (a thin, flexible tube) that is threaded into a large vein above the right side of the heart called the superior vena cava. A port-a-cath is used to give intravenous fluids, blood transfusions, chemotherapy, and other drugs. It is also used for taking blood samples. A port-a-cath may stay in place for weeks or months and helps avoid the need for repeated needle sticks.
